Posts.Content: If there is a Haven Centre near you they offer up to 6 free sessions of treatments, including acupuncture.You can travel from anywhere, and they have workshops, seminars, 1 to 1 treatments etc. www.breastcancerhaven.org.uk/.../where-you-can-find-us
Posts.Title: AIs and acupuncture

Posts.Content: Had she had blood tests to make sure that there isn't an issue with her liver, pancreas or kidneys after the chemo? It could be a way of quickly checking thr basics.
Posts.Title: Sickness weeks after chemo course

Posts.Content: Hi Eva2, Can I ask how much you are paying for Femara, and where you get it from? I'm really sensitive to medication, and suspect I'll end up tring for that brand and not getting it through my GP. I know that it costs the NHS about £90 a month though....
Posts.Title: Letrozole: have Cipla really taken over Accord?

Posts.Content: It's a shame that we're can't group together and buy a few hundred packets from Poland! A few hours overtime would pay for it each month......:) Though you can use a UK prescription in any EU country.  Is it available under other health systems in the EU I wonder?  https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/health/prescription-medicine-abroad/prescriptions/faq/index_en.htm
Posts.Title: Letrozole: have Cipla really taken over Accord?

Posts.Content: Hi Eva2, I just looked up a parallel import, and it's through another EU member state. Will your chemist buy lots before we come out of the EU (if we do?). I'd love to know what they cost in other EU countries, and it's a shame that you can't get the NHS to pay the prescription part of the cost back to you. Let us know how it goes as I'm also dreading the generic brands. The only generic brand I can take of painkillers or antihistamines without side-effects is Boots. It's a shame that they don't have an own-brand version! Good luck!
Posts.Title: Letrozole: have Cipla really taken over Accord?

Posts.Content: Are there any places in the London area similar to the Judy Plume shop recommended in Glasgow? I think that I'll be starting chemo after my lymph node surgery heals a bit, and would like to be prepared before the tiredness.sickness kicks in. Can I also ask what people do at the pool? I'd like to try and swim when possible, but I'm finding it hard to find a nice swimsuit as well as don't know if I want a bald head at the pool look for summer:) Are there any swim wigs, or swim hats with fringe etc? Thanks in advance....
Posts.Title: Where to buy wigs (I live in London)

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone. I'll make an appointment at Trendco once its certain I'm having chemo, as I'd like to try them on and get some help. I'll be on 3-week cycles of EC for the first 3 months and wondered about the third week of each cycle. My local pool also has a lido, so the idea is that I'd go but in the indoor pool which is almost deserted in the summer! I wanted to swim because it's a good exercise I for anyone at risk of lymphodema, but  will check. I'm abandoning a 12 day holiday in Majorca because of treatment so  feeling a bit sorry for myself!
Posts.Title: Where to buy wigs (I live in London)

Posts.Content: Hi,  I had a mastectomy on 18/4 with 2 sentinel notes removed after being diagnosed with early stage breast cancer. I was given am appointment with my consultant for my results this Thursday,  but the hospital have now given me another one for Wednesday as well 'with a consultant' (no name). I've questioned this and they say u should have both.  Is this normal,  or should I be scared!!
Posts.Title: Two appointments now on Wednesday and Thursday for results?

Posts.Content: Thank you. I have an appointment to see a psychotherapist at the hospital in 10 days,  and as I live in London have access to the Haven. So have an acupuncture appointment the day after my results. Then 5 more sessions of either that or aromatherapy massage for free:) I struggled along for years with all these problems,  but understand that this is my breaking point so asked for help before the mastectomy. It is so strange though that even when I distract myself and don't feel stressed my body is going mad! I bought some good quality CBD to try and relax,  but that gives me stomach pains too:/ Anyway,  I hope that you have a lovely bank holiday weekend! X
Posts.Title: Two appointments now on Wednesday and Thursday for results?

Posts.Content: Sadly no.  The breast is clear with good margins,  but I  have one clear sentinel node and one which looked clear on the scan but has a tumor in it:. I'm absolutely terrified as now have a roughly 1/6 chance of further spread.  To go from hormone therapy to having CT and bone scans in the next couple of weeks and if they are ok the rest of my nodes out followed/preceded by 5 months chemo and hormones has made me feel really ill.  I have mild asthma and mild reflux which I usually don't notice,  but they have both become severe after the news and I ache all over.  I haven't told my daughters yet about the new development as my youngest is taking her actual GCSE's and has some mental health issues and my older one has two really important exams coming up.  I can only think the worst as is being going that way a while now. My sister died three years ago,  my mother two years ago, my youngest developed depression,  horrible sister in law didn't pass on 2 mammogram letters last year from the parental family home she's taken over with her daughter and boyfriend despite my husband owning 1/4 off it and our doctors letters going there for over 20 years until she denied us access 19 months ago when her and dh's mother had a stroke.   She's the reason it's this advanced as I should have had a mammogram last summer....... Work is great - they sent me a huge bouquet of flowers when I told them,  friends great,  my daughters school have her down as having extenuating circumstances and promise to take good care if her through the exams. The deputy head had a mastectomy last October with hormones now so is great too. And I'm entitled to 5 months sick leave on full pay. But all that means nothing if I'm terminal.  ......I find out if it's spread in 11 days.  If it has they leave the nodes,  no chemo, just hormones.  They apparently keep chemo for when things are bad. I don't know if other hospitals do that too? If the scans are ok then I'll have my nodes harvested or chemo first, though if only 1-3 affected (please be the case!!!) Then I can have an oncotype test done on thur cancer and enter a trial if the recurrance rate is low to avoid chemo.  Sorry to ramble on,  and thanks for being here. X
Posts.Title: Two appointments now on Wednesday and Thursday for results?

Posts.Content: Hi Claire-H, It sounds like our daughters are about the same age at diagnosis (mine are just turned 16 and 19, with my youngest's birthday  on the day of my mastectomy). I already love this forum for it's support to each other, and it's really interesting to see how treatment varies across the country. I had the first of the two scans yesterday - the bone scan. After the injection (which made me feel suddenly hot!) I sat outside in the hospital gardens in the sunshine with my husband for a little while. He left to collect one of out daughters, and as I was reading there a magpie flew down right in front of me:/  Funny how I keep seeing them at the minute...... Anyway, after greeting it to try and ward off bad luck it's mate called and I then saw them both which was a relief! I don't know if any of you have had a bone scan, but it takes 15 minutes for the whole body one, then 5 minutes for the pelvis and 5 minutes for the chest, followed by about another 5 minutes when they do a low resolution CT scan to allow the different scans to be combined in 3D. It probably took about 50 minutes in total, of which time my arms were above my head for about 25 minutes. I had my mastectomy 19 days before, so could manage it, but was a bit swollen last night and my remaining (hopefully not for long!) nodes feel a bit swollen today. I'm trying not to read too much into that I remember it happened many years ago after a CT scan, and the top of my arm looked a bit different last night too, though slightly better today. At the end the radiographer was cheerful, and happily waved at us, though I know that  it means nothing until the full scan is assessed. I hate this wait though, as the best case scenario is the rest being removed over 4 weeks after the operation, and as I suspect other nodes are affected it could mean the cancer spreading.......oh, well....as everyone says, the wait is the worst!
Posts.Title: Two appointments now on Wednesday and Thursday for results?

Posts.Content: Thanks RubyRose, I contacted my Macmillian nurse, and appointments seemed to have jumped the gun, so to speak, ahead of the breast team. It's with the Oncologist, which I didn't realise would happen as they said the results wouldn't be back in time for this week's team meeting. Fingers crossed now:)
Posts.Title: Two appointments now on Wednesday and Thursday for results?

Posts.Content: Having positive nodes does mean more treatment, as you'll need surgery or at least radiotherapy on them depending on what the sentinel nodes had. You'll probably have some scans (I had a bone scan and a couple of CT scans followed by a liver MRI one) for staging as well which I found scary, but to the breast team is just routine. . About a third of women are node positive so it's not something unusual, just means more (not so great !) treatment.  I had a level 1 and 2 node clearance yesterday so have the dreaded bottle again and a stiff arm, and looking at my letter unexpectedly given TARGIT (which I thought was only for lumpectomies) as well. Hi Pmess, What trial are you taking part in? Is it a new drug or new combination?
Posts.Title: Sentinel node positive

Posts.Content: I saw the POSNOC trial,  if you're taking part in it then it would suggest that you have micro-mets on your node/s. There's a lot of evidence in Europe and the USA to support that, so lucky you:))  I don't know the results from my clearance yet,  but the one which was  positive was too big for that trial or the other opton of radiotherapy alone. I'm still surprised to have been given TARGIT, where a small ball is inserted during surgery (usually into a lumpectomy) to give the radiotherapy as a one-off treatment instead of 20+ daily external ones, and with better results and fewer side effects.   The doctor who invented it works at my hospital, but I wasn't aware of it being used on the nodes before,  so it was a pleasant surprise (in as much as radiotherapy can be!) Good luck with your treatment. Are you going straight to the AI tablets (like Letrozole), or do you need any other treatment first like radiotherapy? X
Posts.Title: Sentinel node positive

Posts.Content: I was being good this time until today, I even preemptively taped the connection above the valve c.8cms from where it's stitched in place so that when I forgot about it  I'd not pull it out by the valve and break the vacuum like last time. This is day 4, and I've just walked away forgetting it so now have a lovely throbbing sensation in my armpit! Has anyone here NOT forgotten they had one?
Posts.Title: Drain Bottles!
